laboratory_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation with an 8-mm gap; no degenerative osteoarthritis.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up examination 13.5 years later revealed mild intermittent pain, no new symptoms, and no clinical or radiographic deterioration.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Radiographs showed bilateral scapholunate dissociation, with a wider separation on the right; right wrist osteoarthritis was modest.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up examination 29 months later revealed pain and weakness bilaterally, more severe on the right, with symptoms aggravated by lifting.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Left scapholunate dissociation with scapholunate ligament perforation.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Initial follow-up showed excellent resolution of pain; comparison radiographs later revealed an identical gap between scaphoid and lunate, unchanged symptoms at the last follow-up.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation with no arthritic changes.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up 13 months later revealed continued mild pain and left wrist popping sensations, reporting no weakness or worsening overall.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation with positive provocative tests, full range of motion.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Follow-up 15 months later revealed no symptoms and no weakness; full range of motion maintained.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Bilateral scapholunate dissociation confirmed by arthrograms.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Last follow-up examination 6 months later showed mild wrist pain with twisting and lifting, no new symptoms, no change in activities.
